explanations.A: Not quite, the amount of pizza that was originally left is already given to us in the question as 3/4. Have a think about what it means to divide an amount...
explanations.B: If each serving was 6, we would be dividing 3/4 between 6 but 6 is the answer, not the divisor! Have a think about what the answer to any division tells us about the two numbers we are dividing...
explanations.C: If it was 'left over' slices, that would suggest 6 was a remainder of the division, however it is the full answer and not just what is left over. Have a think about what the answer to any division tells us about the two numbers we are dividing...
explanations.D: A division tells us how many times a divisor can fit into a dividend. If 1/8 can fit into 3/4 6 times, that means that 6 servings of 1/8 of the pizza can be made!

explanations.A: A division tells us how many times a divisor can fit into a dividend. If 1/12 can fit into 2/3 8 times, that means that 8 servings can be made!
explanations.B: Not quite, the amount of cake that was originally left is already given to us in the question as 2/3. Have a think about what it means to divide an amount...
explanations.C: If each serving was 8, we would be dividing 2/3 between 8 but 8 is the answer, not the divisor! Have a think about what the answer to any division tells us about the two numbers we are dividing...
explanations.D: If it was 'left over' servings, that would suggest 8 was a remainder of the division, however it is the full answer and not just what is left over. Have a think about what the answer to any division tells us about the two numbers we are dividing...

explanations.A: Not quite, the question already tells us that the large chocolate bar weighs 4/5 of a pound, so it can't weigh 8 pounds! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.B: We want to split 4/5 of a pound of chocolate into 1/10 groups by dividing, which gives us an answer of 8. This means that 8 groups (or portions) of 1/10 can be made from 4/5 of a pound.
explanations.C: Not quite, the question already tells us that the portions weigh 1/10 of a pound each, so one can't weigh 8 pounds! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.D: The question is only telling us about one large chocolate bar, so there can't be 8 of them! If we are dividing a chocolate bar into parts, what would each part represent?

explanations.A: We want to split 5/8 of a pound of cashews into 1/16 groups by dividing, which gives us an answer of 10. This means that 10 groups (or portions) of 1/16 can be made from 5/8 of a pound.
explanations.B: Not quite, the question already tells us that the portions weigh 1/16 of a pound each, so one can't weigh 10 pounds! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.C: This isn't something that we could work out from this question, as it's about sharing 5/8 of a pound of cashews into portions of 1/16. What might the number of times 1/16 can fit into 5/8 tell us?
explanations.D: Not quite, the question already tells us that the bag weighs 5/8 of a pound! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...

explanations.A: We are dividing 7/8 metre of ribbon into 1/4 metre strips. The answer to the division is 3 1/2, which means we could make 3 1/2 strips of 1/4 metre of ribbon.
explanations.B: Not quite, the question already tells us that the original piece of ribbon is 7/8 of a metre long! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.C: Not quite, the question already tells us that each smaller piece of ribbon is 1/4 metre long! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.D: If it was 'left over' then this would be a remainder, but 3 1/2 is the answer to the division, not the remainder!

explanations.A: Not quite, the question already tells us that the original piece of board is 15/16 feet long! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.B: Not quite, the question already tells us that each smaller piece of board is 1/4 foot long! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.C: If it was 'left over' then this would be a remainder, but 3 3/4 is the answer to the division, not the remainder!
explanations.D: We are dividing 15/16 foot of board into 1/4 foot pieces. The answer to the division is 3 3/4, which means we could make 3 3/4 pieces of 1/4 foot of board.

explanations.A: Not quite, the question already tells us that the entire plot of land is 3/4 of a square metre! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.B: We are dividing 3/4 square metre of land into 1/12 square metre sections. The answer to the division is 9, which means the farmer could make 9 sections of land.
explanations.C: This actually isn't that relevant to the question. If we are dividing pieces of land, then the answer is going to give us information about the pieces of land...
explanations.D: Not quite, the question already tells us that each section needs to be 1/12 of a square metre. Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...

explanations.A: Not quite, the question already tells us that each section needs to be 1/18 of a square metre. Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.B: This actually isn't that relevant to the question. If we are dividing an area into smaller sections of mosaic, then the answer is going to give us information about the sections of mosaic...
explanations.C: We are dividing 5/6 square metre of mosaic into 1/18 metre sections. The answer to the division is 15, which means the artist could make 15 sections of mosaic.
explanations.D: Not quite, the question already tells us that the entire mosaic is 5/6 of a square metre! Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...

explanations.A: When we divide, we are trying to see how many 1/4s go into 1 1/2. We can work that out by doing the division, which would therefore tell us how many glasses worth of juice can be made from the bottle.
explanations.B: Not quite, the question already tells us that the bottle has 1 1/2 litres of juice. Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.C: Not quite, the question already tells us that each glass can hold 1/4 of a litre. Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.D: This would be the answer to a subtraction if one glass worth of juice was poured out, not a division. A division tells us how many 1/4s can fit into 1 1/2!

explanations.A: Not quite, the question already tells us that the jug has 1 1/3 gallons of milk. Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
explanations.B: When we divide, we are trying to see how many 1/12s go into 1 1/3. We can work that out by doing the division, which would therefore tell us how many glasses worth of milk can be made from the jug.
explanations.C: This would be the answer to a subtraction if one glass worth of milk was poured out, not a division. A division tells us how many 1/12s can fit into 1 1/3!
explanations.D: Not quite, the question already tells us that each glass can hold 1/12 of a gallon. Have a think about what a division tells us about two numbers...
